title: Is the human race inherently violent or is violence a learned attribute? - Quora

response.answer_text: https://www.quora.com/Why-do-humans-have-a-tendency-for-violence/answer/Dan-Robb-2: Since I was a2a, we have genetic predispositions established "by natural selection over millions of years," leading to "innate behaviors ... so useful that they became encoded into the tiny, cryptic language of DNA" (Eagleman, 2011, p. 87). Homicide has been effective in preventing harm to self or family, protecting reputation and social status, protecting resources, and eliminating competition for resources (to the extent of elimination of “defective” individuals, even if genetically related) (Duntley & Buss, 2008). Social order has evolved more quickly than the physiological apparatus (i.e., our brains) that operationalizes thought leading to behavior; meaning that the trait of aggression is still ingrained biologically. Walsh and Beaver (2008, p. 23) stated that “the suite of traits useful for focusing on mating effort includes deceitfulness,impulsiveness, sensation-seeking, and aggression; traits useful for focusing on parenting effort include empathy, conscientiousness, and altruism.”  Apparently, as life has been facilitated by technological advancement, and scarce resources have therefore become less scarce, the pro-social parenting traits have become more in evidence. “Our ancestors were far more violent than we are, that violence has been in decline for long stretches of time, and that today we are probably living in the most peaceful time in our species' existence. … Until 10,000 years ago, all humans lived as hunter-gatherers, without permanent settlements or government. … Looking at casualty rates among contemporary hunter-gatherers,which is our best source of evidence about this way of life,has shown … (an) almost a 60 percent chance that a man will die at the hands of another man, … (when compared to) the 20th century, there would have been two billion deaths rather than 100 million” (Pinker,2007). References: Eagleman, D., (2011).Incognito: The secret lives of the brain. New York: Pantheon Books.
